children.text: Children playing. Footage from Afrique 50 by René Vautier.
Man in suit rides trolley and goes to a café
Old man asks for cigarettes, interacts with other Africans outside of a restaurant, in the streets
Children in street playing in the gutters, watching merry-go-round
Man gets in a taxi, seemingly guiding the visit of Paris that happens in this section
Shots of various women and men
Woman in dress, played by Marapessa Dawn, waits for her lover while being watched by another man
Two men in suits, who separate, and one continues walking with a white lady to the metro
Man in suit joins his friends for dinner
Man enters the bar, greets a couple of people, and looks around for someone inside the bar while others dance
Walking in street out of bar
Under the patronage of the ethnographic fim committee
and our elders, we would shout our independence.
ignorant of the world around us
Knowing nothing but our little corner of Africa
We didn't know other regions existed,
The time of the kingdom of children.
We had to grow up, leave home for Paris,
capital of the world, capital of Black Africa.
Here, mists have replace the sun.
Machine noises, those of men of nature.
But Paris is the centre of hope,
Paris is also the city of promises
made by young men to help their country.
where are your gold-paved streets from our nusery books?
civilization, at the school of outstretched hands.
the Latin Quarter, home to students
- O, llustrious dead of the Panthéon -
who are found, when they can be found,
Paris, streets of gold in fairy tales for black children.
And may they turn, may they turn
we have the hope of finding ourselves,
Salute the genius of men of liberty,
Salute all the monuments of Paris.
Witnesses of glories past and present.
The world, in the Latin Quarter, assembles itself,
to try to melt, in the sun of love,
the ancient barriers of prejudice and monuments of hate,
in order to bring closer, in order to understand,
on the history of good peoples.
and a fraternity of principle, without warmth,
The fruits of the earth for all,
the fruits of culture for all.
And it's in this old quarter
that the wind of hope blows,
the wind of happiness and of love.
the heart open and the arms outstretched,
side by side, beyond the darkness,
we are winning the battle of light.
Afrique-sur-Seine is a collective film made in 1955
by Paulin Soumanou Vieyra and Mamadou Sarr.
the film has been restored from an interpositive,
the best photochemical element known to exist.
This incomplete copy included many black frames.
To make the movie more watchable,
it was decided to establish a digital version of the remaining master
and to delete the black frames we could not recreate,
The soundtrack, rescued from a 16mm sound negative
and longer than the restored images,
has been edited and adapted for more comfortable listening.
The original file has been digitally preserved.
This film is a part of the African Film Library's restoration plan
initiated by the CPCA (African film heritage committee)
et des ayeurs, nous crions alors notre l'independence.
ignorant du monde qui nous entourer.
Nous ignorions le region qui limiter notre coin d'Afrique.
Nous ignorions qui peut-etait exister d'autres regions
ou des petits noirs, les petits jaunes,
Les temps du royaume des enfants.
Les enfants de toute la terre.
Il fallu grandir et quitter le pays pour Paris,
capital du monde, capital de l'Afrique Noire.
Ici,la brume a remplace le soleil.
Les cles(?) des machines, ceux des hommes de nature.
Mais Paris est le centre d'espoir,
Paris est aussi le ville de promesses
faite par les jeunes alors pays des aides.
ou sont donc les chemins en or de nos contes enfant?
la civilisation a l'ecole de mains entendue.
sont encore la Rue de Medicis,
la quartier latin, ou le chez soi pour les etudiants.
ceux trouve quand il se trouve,
